title: 109_hr2936
content: The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to cover second opinions under the Public Health Service Act. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide or authorize second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals when requested by participants, beneficiaries, or enrollees questioning surgical procedures, diagnoses, or unclear clinical indications. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to offer second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals when there are unclear clinical indications, conflicting test results, or if the treatment plan is not improving the medical condition within a reasonable time frame. An appropriately qualified health care professional is defined as a primary care physician or a specialist. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide timely second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals, defined as primary care physicians or specialists with relevant clinical expertise. Opinions must be rendered promptly, especially in cases of imminent health threats or potential loss of life or function. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to provide timely second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals for cases involving emergency needs or urgent care. Plans must establish timelines for responding to second opinion requests and make them available to the public. Participants are only responsible for applicable copayments for approved second opinions. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to offer timely second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals for emergency or urgent care cases. Participants are responsible for copayments for approved second opinions, with specific guidelines for primary care and specialist referrals. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to provide timely second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals. If a specialist outside the network is needed, the plan must cover the cost or negotiate fees. If no participating provider meets the standard, the plan must authorize a second opinion from a qualified professional outside the network. The plan is not responsible for travel costs. The plan or issuer must consider the participant's ability to travel to the provider when selecting the provider network. Second opinion health professionals must provide consultation reports to the participant and initial health professional. If a request for a second opinion is denied, the participant must be informed in writing of the reasons and their right to file a grievance. Authorization for additional medical opinions can be granted by the plan. The participant must be notified in writing of denial reasons and their right to file a grievance. Services must be obtained from participating providers unless authorized by the plan. Exemption applies to preferred provider contracts that do not limit second opinions. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements. Preferred provider contracts that do not limit second opinions must comply with notice requirements. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 include adding a new section regarding group health plans. "SEC. 714. COVERAGE OF SECOND OPINIONS." The provisions of section 2707 apply to group health plans and insurance coverage. Notice of requirements must be provided within 60 days of the first plan year. Amendments are made to sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act. Amendments are made to section 732(a) of the Act by inserting new item after section 713 in the table of contents. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code and the Public Health Service Act to include coverage of second opinions in healthcare plans. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act require health insurance issuers to comply with certain notice requirements and apply provisions to individual market coverage similar to group health plans. Effective dates for these amendments vary for group and individual health plans. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act apply to group health plans starting from January 1, 2006, and to individual health insurance coverage in the individual market on or after that date. There is an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment, with a delayed application until the termination of the agreements or January 1, 2006. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services must coordinate regulations and policies to ensure consistency in enforcing the provisions of the Act. The Secretaries must coordinate enforcement of the Act to ensure consistent implementation and avoid duplication of efforts.
